trans-unit.source: Create a Node.js chat application with Socket.IO in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Create a Node.js chat application with Socket.IO in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: A tutorial that demonstrates using socket.io in a node.js web app hosted on Azure.
trans-unit.target: A tutorial that demonstrates using socket.io in a node.js web app hosted on Azure.

trans-unit.source: Create a Node.js chat application with Socket.IO in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Create a Node.js chat application with Socket.IO in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Socket.IO provides real-time communication between your node.js server and clients using WebSockets.
trans-unit.target: Socket.IO provides real-time communication between your node.js server and clients using WebSockets.

trans-unit.source: It also supports fallback to other transports (such as long polling) that work with older browsers.
trans-unit.target: It also supports fallback to other transports (such as long polling) that work with older browsers.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial will walk you through hosting a Socket.IO based chat application as an Azure web app, and show you how to <link><linkText>scale</linkText><title></title></link> the application using <link><linkText>Azure Redis Cache</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial will walk you through hosting a Socket.IO based chat application as an Azure web app, and show you how to <link><linkText>scale</linkText><title></title></link> the application using <link><linkText>Azure Redis Cache</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: For more information on Socket.IO, see <link><linkText>http://socket.io/[socketio]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on Socket.IO, see <link><linkText>http://socket.io/[socketio]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The procedures in this task apply to <link><linkText>App Service Web Apps</linkText><title></title></link>; for Cloud Services, see <html></html>Build a Node.js Chat Application with Socket.IO on an Azure Cloud Service<html></html>.
trans-unit.target: The procedures in this task apply to <link><linkText>App Service Web Apps</linkText><title></title></link>; for Cloud Services, see <html></html>Build a Node.js Chat Application with Socket.IO on an Azure Cloud Service<html></html>.

trans-unit.source: Download the chat example
trans-unit.target: Download the chat example

trans-unit.source: For this project, we will use the chat example from the [Socket.IO
trans-unit.target: For this project, we will use the chat example from the [Socket.IO

trans-unit.source: GitHub repository].
trans-unit.target: GitHub repository].

trans-unit.source: Perform the following steps to download the example
trans-unit.target: Perform the following steps to download the example

trans-unit.source: and add it to the project you previously created.
trans-unit.target: and add it to the project you previously created.

trans-unit.source: Download a <link><linkText>ZIP or GZ archived release[release]</linkText><title></title></link> of the Socket.IO project (version 1.3.5 was used for this document)
trans-unit.target: Download a <link><linkText>ZIP or GZ archived release[release]</linkText><title></title></link> of the Socket.IO project (version 1.3.5 was used for this document)

trans-unit.source: Extract the archive and copy the examples\\chat
trans-unit.target: Extract the archive and copy the examples\\chat

trans-unit.source: directory to a new location.
trans-unit.target: directory to a new location.

trans-unit.source: For example,
trans-unit.target: For example,

trans-unit.source: \\node\\chat.
trans-unit.target: \\node\\chat.

trans-unit.source: Modify app.js and install modules
trans-unit.target: Modify app.js and install modules

trans-unit.source: Rename the index.js file to app.js.
trans-unit.target: Rename the index.js file to app.js.

trans-unit.source: This allows Azure to detect that this is a Node.js application.
trans-unit.target: This allows Azure to detect that this is a Node.js application.

trans-unit.source: Open the app.js file in a text editor.
trans-unit.target: Open the app.js file in a text editor.

trans-unit.source: Change the line containing var io = require('../..')(server); as shown below:
trans-unit.target: Change the line containing var io = require('../..')(server); as shown below:

trans-unit.source: Open the package.json file and add a reference to socket.io under dependencies, as shown below:
trans-unit.target: Open the package.json file and add a reference to socket.io under dependencies, as shown below:

trans-unit.source: From the command-line, change to the \\node\\chat directory and use npm to install the modules required by this application:
trans-unit.target: From the command-line, change to the \\node\\chat directory and use npm to install the modules required by this application:

trans-unit.source: This will install the modules into a subfolder named node_modules.
trans-unit.target: This will install the modules into a subfolder named node_modules.

trans-unit.source: Create an Azure Web App
trans-unit.target: Create an Azure Web App

trans-unit.source: Follow these steps to create an Azure web app, enable Git publishing, and then enable WebSocket support for the web app.
trans-unit.target: Follow these steps to create an Azure web app, enable Git publishing, and then enable WebSocket support for the web app.

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you need an Azure account.
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you need an Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.

trans-unit.source: For details, see <html></html>Azure Free Trial<html></html>.
trans-unit.target: For details, see <html></html>Azure Free Trial<html></html>.

trans-unit.source: Install the Azure Command-Line Interface (Azure CLI) and connect to your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Install the Azure Command-Line Interface (Azure CLI) and connect to your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Install and Configure the Azure CLI</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Install and Configure the Azure CLI</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If this is your first time setting up a repository in Azure, you need to create login credentials.
trans-unit.target: If this is your first time setting up a repository in Azure, you need to create login credentials.

trans-unit.source: From the Azure CLI, enter the following command:
trans-unit.target: From the Azure CLI, enter the following command:

trans-unit.source: Change to the \\node\chat directory and use the following command to create a new Azure web app and a local Git repository.
trans-unit.target: Change to the \\node\chat directory and use the following command to create a new Azure web app and a local Git repository.

trans-unit.source: This command also creates a Git remote named 'azure'.
trans-unit.target: This command also creates a Git remote named 'azure'.

trans-unit.source: You must replace 'mysitename' with a unique name for your web app.
trans-unit.target: You must replace 'mysitename' with a unique name for your web app.

trans-unit.source: Commit the existing files to the local repository by using the following commands:
trans-unit.target: Commit the existing files to the local repository by using the following commands:

trans-unit.source: Push the files to the Azure Web Apps repository with the following command:
trans-unit.target: Push the files to the Azure Web Apps repository with the following command:

trans-unit.source: When prompted, enter your credentials from step 2.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, enter your credentials from step 2.

trans-unit.source: You will receive status messages as modules are imported on the server.
trans-unit.target: You will receive status messages as modules are imported on the server.

trans-unit.source: Once this process has completed, the application will be hosted on your Azure web app.
trans-unit.target: Once this process has completed, the application will be hosted on your Azure web app.

trans-unit.source: During module installation, you may notice errors that 'The imported project ... was not found'.
trans-unit.target: During module installation, you may notice errors that 'The imported project ... was not found'.

trans-unit.source: These can safely be ignored.
trans-unit.target: These can safely be ignored.

trans-unit.source: Socket.IO uses WebSockets, which are not enabled by default on Azure.
trans-unit.target: Socket.IO uses WebSockets, which are not enabled by default on Azure.

trans-unit.source: To enable web sockets, use the following command:
trans-unit.target: To enable web sockets, use the following command:

trans-unit.source: If prompted, enter the name of the web app.
trans-unit.target: If prompted, enter the name of the web app.

trans-unit.source: The 'azure site set -w' command will work only with version 0.7.4 or higher of the Azure Command-Line Interface.
trans-unit.target: The 'azure site set -w' command will work only with version 0.7.4 or higher of the Azure Command-Line Interface.

trans-unit.source: You can also enable WebSocket support using the <link><linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can also enable WebSocket support using the <link><linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To enable WebSockets using the Azure Portal, click the web app from the Web Apps blade, click All settings > Application settings.
trans-unit.target: To enable WebSockets using the Azure Portal, click the web app from the Web Apps blade, click All settings > Application settings.

trans-unit.source: Under Web Sockets, click On.
trans-unit.target: Under Web Sockets, click On.

trans-unit.source: Then click Save.
trans-unit.target: Then click Save.

trans-unit.source: To view the web app on Azure, use the following command to launch your web browser and navigate to the hosted web app:
trans-unit.target: To view the web app on Azure, use the following command to launch your web browser and navigate to the hosted web app:

trans-unit.source: Your app is now running on Azure, and can relay chat messages between different clients using Socket.IO.
trans-unit.target: Your app is now running on Azure, and can relay chat messages between different clients using Socket.IO.

trans-unit.source: Scale out
trans-unit.target: Scale out

trans-unit.source: Socket.IO applications can be scaled out by using an adapter to distribute messages and events between multiple application instances.
trans-unit.target: Socket.IO applications can be scaled out by using an adapter to distribute messages and events between multiple application instances.

trans-unit.source: While there are several adapters available, the <link><linkText>socket.io-redis</linkText><title></title></link> adapter can be easily used with the Azure Redis Cache feature.
trans-unit.target: While there are several adapters available, the <link><linkText>socket.io-redis</linkText><title></title></link> adapter can be easily used with the Azure Redis Cache feature.

trans-unit.source: An additional requirement for scaling out a Socket.IO solution is support for sticky sessions.
trans-unit.target: An additional requirement for scaling out a Socket.IO solution is support for sticky sessions.

trans-unit.source: Sticky sessions are enabled by default for Azure Web Apps through Azure Request Routing.
trans-unit.target: Sticky sessions are enabled by default for Azure Web Apps through Azure Request Routing.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Instance Affinity in Azure Web Sites</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Instance Affinity in Azure Web Sites</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Create a Redis cache
trans-unit.target: Create a Redis cache

trans-unit.source: Perform the steps in <link><linkText>Create a cache in Azure Redis Cache</linkText><title></title></link> to create a new cache.
trans-unit.target: Perform the steps in <link><linkText>Create a cache in Azure Redis Cache</linkText><title></title></link> to create a new cache.

trans-unit.source: Save the Host name and Primary key for your cache, as these will be needed in the next steps.
trans-unit.target: Save the Host name and Primary key for your cache, as these will be needed in the next steps.

trans-unit.source: Add the redis and socket.io-redis modules
trans-unit.target: Add the redis and socket.io-redis modules

trans-unit.source: From a command-line, change to the \\node\\chat directory and use the following command.
trans-unit.target: From a command-line, change to the \\node\\chat directory and use the following command.

trans-unit.source: The versions specified in this command are the versions used when testing this article.
trans-unit.target: The versions specified in this command are the versions used when testing this article.

trans-unit.source: Modify the app.js file to add the following lines immediately after var io = require('socket.io')(server);
trans-unit.target: Modify the app.js file to add the following lines immediately after var io = require('socket.io')(server);

trans-unit.source: Replace redishostname and rediskey with the host name and key for your Redis cache.
trans-unit.target: Replace redishostname and rediskey with the host name and key for your Redis cache.

trans-unit.source: This will create a publish and subscribe client to the Redis cache created previously.
trans-unit.target: This will create a publish and subscribe client to the Redis cache created previously.

trans-unit.source: The clients are then used with the adapter to configure Socket.IO to use the Redis cache for passing messages and events between instances of your application
trans-unit.target: The clients are then used with the adapter to configure Socket.IO to use the Redis cache for passing messages and events between instances of your application

trans-unit.source: While the socket.io-redis adapter can communicate directly to Redis, the current version does not support the authentication required by Azure Redis cache.
trans-unit.target: While the socket.io-redis adapter can communicate directly to Redis, the current version does not support the authentication required by Azure Redis cache.

trans-unit.source: So the initial connection is created using the redis module, then the client is passed to the socket.io-redis adapter.
trans-unit.target: So the initial connection is created using the redis module, then the client is passed to the socket.io-redis adapter.

trans-unit.source: While Azure Redis Cache supports secure connections using port 6380, the modules used in this example do not support secure connections as of 7/14/2014.
trans-unit.target: While Azure Redis Cache supports secure connections using port 6380, the modules used in this example do not support secure connections as of 7/14/2014.

trans-unit.source: The above code uses the default, unsecure port of 6380.
trans-unit.target: The above code uses the default, unsecure port of 6380.

trans-unit.source: Save the modified app.js
trans-unit.target: Save the modified app.js

trans-unit.source: Commit changes and redeploy
trans-unit.target: Commit changes and redeploy

trans-unit.source: From the command-line in the \\node\\chat directory, use the following commands to commit changes and redeploy the application.
trans-unit.target: From the command-line in the \\node\\chat directory, use the following commands to commit changes and redeploy the application.

trans-unit.source: Once the changes have been pushed to the server, you can scale your site across multiple instances by using the following command.
trans-unit.target: Once the changes have been pushed to the server, you can scale your site across multiple instances by using the following command.

trans-unit.source: Where # is the number of instances to create.
trans-unit.target: Where # is the number of instances to create.

trans-unit.source: You can connect to your web app from multiple browsers or computers to verify that messages are correctly sent to all clients.
trans-unit.target: You can connect to your web app from multiple browsers or computers to verify that messages are correctly sent to all clients.

trans-unit.source: Troubleshooting
trans-unit.target: Troubleshooting

trans-unit.source: Connection limits
trans-unit.target: Connection limits

trans-unit.source: Azure Web Apps is available in multiple SKUs, which determine the resources available to your site.
trans-unit.target: Azure Web Apps is available in multiple SKUs, which determine the resources available to your site.

trans-unit.source: This includes the number of allowed WebSocket connections.
trans-unit.target: This includes the number of allowed WebSocket connections.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the <link><linkText>Web Apps Pricing page[pricing]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the <link><linkText>Web Apps Pricing page[pricing]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Messages aren't being sent using WebSockets
trans-unit.target: Messages aren't being sent using WebSockets

trans-unit.source: If client browsers keep falling back to long polling instead of using WebSockets, it may be because of one of the following.
trans-unit.target: If client browsers keep falling back to long polling instead of using WebSockets, it may be because of one of the following.

trans-unit.source: Try limiting the transport to just WebSockets
trans-unit.target: Try limiting the transport to just WebSockets

trans-unit.source: In order for Socket.IO to use WebSockets as the messaging transport, both the server and client must support WebSockets.
trans-unit.target: In order for Socket.IO to use WebSockets as the messaging transport, both the server and client must support WebSockets.

trans-unit.source: If one or the other does not, Socket.IO will negotiate another transport, such as long polling.
trans-unit.target: If one or the other does not, Socket.IO will negotiate another transport, such as long polling.

trans-unit.source: The default list of transports used by Socket.IO is websocket, htmlfile, xhr-polling, jsonp-polling.
trans-unit.target: The default list of transports used by Socket.IO is websocket, htmlfile, xhr-polling, jsonp-polling.

trans-unit.source: You can force it to only use WebSockets by adding the following code to the app.js file, after the line containing , nicknames = {};.
trans-unit.target: You can force it to only use WebSockets by adding the following code to the app.js file, after the line containing , nicknames = {};.

trans-unit.source: Note that older browsers that do not support WebSockets will not be able to connect to the site while the above code is active, as it restricts communication to WebSockets only.
trans-unit.target: Note that older browsers that do not support WebSockets will not be able to connect to the site while the above code is active, as it restricts communication to WebSockets only.

trans-unit.source: Use SSL
trans-unit.target: Use SSL

trans-unit.source: WebSockets relies on some lesser used HTTP headers, such as the Upgrade header.
trans-unit.target: WebSockets relies on some lesser used HTTP headers, such as the Upgrade header.

trans-unit.source: Some intermediate network devices, such as web proxies, may remove these headers.
trans-unit.target: Some intermediate network devices, such as web proxies, may remove these headers.

trans-unit.source: To avoid this problem, you can establish the WebSocket connection over SSL.
trans-unit.target: To avoid this problem, you can establish the WebSocket connection over SSL.

trans-unit.source: An easy way to accomplish this is to configure Socket.IO to match origin protocol.
trans-unit.target: An easy way to accomplish this is to configure Socket.IO to match origin protocol.

trans-unit.source: This instructs Socket.IO to secure WebSockets communication the same as the originating HTTP/HTTPS request for the web page.
trans-unit.target: This instructs Socket.IO to secure WebSockets communication the same as the originating HTTP/HTTPS request for the web page.

trans-unit.source: If a browser uses an HTTPS URL to visit your website, subsequent WebSocket communications through Socket.IO will be secured over SSL.
trans-unit.target: If a browser uses an HTTPS URL to visit your website, subsequent WebSocket communications through Socket.IO will be secured over SSL.

trans-unit.source: To modify this example to enable this configuration, add the following code to the app.js file after the line containing , nicknames = {};.
trans-unit.target: To modify this example to enable this configuration, add the following code to the app.js file after the line containing , nicknames = {};.

trans-unit.source: Verify web.config settings
trans-unit.target: Verify web.config settings

trans-unit.source: Azure web apps that host Node.js applications use the web.config file to route incoming requests to the Node.js application.
trans-unit.target: Azure web apps that host Node.js applications use the web.config file to route incoming requests to the Node.js application.

trans-unit.source: For WebSockets to function correctly with Node.js applications, the web.config must contain the following entry.
trans-unit.target: For WebSockets to function correctly with Node.js applications, the web.config must contain the following entry.

trans-unit.source: This disables the IIS WebSockets module, which includes its own implementation of WebSockets and conflicts with Node.js specific WebSocket modules such as Socket.IO.
trans-unit.target: This disables the IIS WebSockets module, which includes its own implementation of WebSockets and conflicts with Node.js specific WebSocket modules such as Socket.IO.

trans-unit.source: If this line is not present, or is set to true, this may be the reason that the WebSocket transport is not working for your application.
trans-unit.target: If this line is not present, or is set to true, this may be the reason that the WebSocket transport is not working for your application.

trans-unit.source: Normally, Node.js applications do not include a web.config file, so Azure Websites will automatically generate one for Node.js applications when they are deployed.
trans-unit.target: Normally, Node.js applications do not include a web.config file, so Azure Websites will automatically generate one for Node.js applications when they are deployed.

trans-unit.source: Since this file is automatically generated on the server, you must use the FTP or FTPS URL for your website to view this file.
trans-unit.target: Since this file is automatically generated on the server, you must use the FTP or FTPS URL for your website to view this file.

trans-unit.source: You can find the FTP and FTPS URLs for your site in the Azure Management portal by selecting your website, and then the Dashboard link.
trans-unit.target: You can find the FTP and FTPS URLs for your site in the Azure Management portal by selecting your website, and then the Dashboard link.

trans-unit.source: The URLs are displayed in the quick glance section.
trans-unit.target: The URLs are displayed in the quick glance section.

trans-unit.source: The web.config file is only generated by Azure Websites if your application does not provide one.
trans-unit.target: The web.config file is only generated by Azure Websites if your application does not provide one.

trans-unit.source: If you provide a web.config file in the root of your application project, it will be used by Azure Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: If you provide a web.config file in the root of your application project, it will be used by Azure Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: If the entry is not present, or is set to a value of true, then you should create a web.config in the root of your Node.js application and specify a value of false.
trans-unit.target: If the entry is not present, or is set to a value of true, then you should create a web.config in the root of your Node.js application and specify a value of false.

trans-unit.source: For reference, the below is a default web.config for an application that uses app.js as the entry point.
trans-unit.target: For reference, the below is a default web.config for an application that uses app.js as the entry point.

trans-unit.source: If your application uses an entry point other than app.js, you must replace all occurrences of app.js with the correct entry point.
trans-unit.target: If your application uses an entry point other than app.js, you must replace all occurrences of app.js with the correct entry point.

trans-unit.source: For example, replacing app.js with server.js.
trans-unit.target: For example, replacing app.js with server.js.

trans-unit.source: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <link><linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <link><linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.

trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial you learned how to create a chat application hosted in an Azure web app.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial you learned how to create a chat application hosted in an Azure web app.

trans-unit.source: You can also host this application as an Azure Cloud Service.
trans-unit.target: You can also host this application as an Azure Cloud Service.

trans-unit.target: For steps on how to accomplish this, see <link><linkText>Build a Node.js Chat Application with Socket.IO on an Azure Cloud Service[cloudservice]</linkText><title></title></link>.
